In Annotea, annotations are typed. It is possible to subclass _Annotation_ into more specific annotation classes with their own properties. In AO we adopt a similar mechanism to cover *much more than simple tagging: comments, notes, examples, erratum, definition, hypothesis, claims, research questions...* all with respect to the existing ontologies.

== Basic Types ==

=== Annotation Type: Qualifier ===

Using Qualifier(s) is equivalent in tagging a document where, instead of a free text tag, a specific entity - identified by a URI - has been used. 

[http://annotation-ontology.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/images/Image%20Annotation%20-%20AO%20Annotation%20Ontology%20-%20by%20Paolo%20Ciccarese.png]<br/>
<b>Figure 1 - Example of annotation of type Qualifier. The annotation is performed on a section of an image.</b>

The RDF of the example in picture 3 would look like the following:
{{{
    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://my.example.org/ann/82400">
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="Qualifier"/>
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/annotation-ns#Annotation"/>
        <ann:annotates rdf:resource="http://tinyurl.com/35a6fnq"/>
        <ann:context rdf:resource="http://my.example.org/sel/20300"/>
        <ao:hasTopic rdf:resource="http://my.example.org/sn/000004015"/>
        <pav:createdOn>2010-03-21</pav:createdOn>
        <pav:createdBy rdf:resource="http://www.hcklab.org/foaf.rdf#me"/>
    </rdf:Description>
}}}

the image selector:

{{{
    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://my.example.org/sn/000004015">
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="ImageSelector"/>
        ...
    </rdf:Description>
}}}

=== Annotation Type: Note ===

[http://annotation-ontology.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/images/Image%20Annotation%20Note%20-%20AO%20Annotation%20Ontology%20-%20by%20Paolo%20Ciccarese.png]<br/>
<b>Figure 2 - Example of note with AO. As it was happening in Annotea, in AO we subclass the Annotation class into a more specific annotation class. In this case we have a Note regarding a portion of an image. An _Image Selector_ has been used.</b>

The RDF of the example in picture 4 would look like the following:
{{{
    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://my.example.org/ann/82400">
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="Note"/>
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/annotation-ns#Annotation"/>
        <ann:annotates rdf:resource="http://tinyurl.com/35a6fnq"/>
        <ann:context rdf:resource="http://my.example.org/sel/20300"/>
        <ann:body>This visual cluster is probably representing the Foo Community</ann:body>
        <pav:createdOn>2010-03-21</pav:createdOn>
        <pav:createdBy rdf:resource="http://www.hcklab.org/foaf.rdf#me"/>
    </rdf:Description>
}}}

the image selector:

{{{
    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://my.example.org/sel/20300">
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="ImageSelector"/>
        ...
    </rdf:Description>
}}}

== Integration with other ontologies ==

=== Annotation Type: SWAN Research Question ===

{{{
    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://my.example.org/ann/82400">
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swan.mindinformatics.org/ontologies/1.2/discourse-elements/ResearchQuestion"/>
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2000/10/annotation-ns#Annotation"/>
        <ann:annotates rdf:resource="http://tinyurl.com/35a6fnq"/>
        ...
        <pav:createdOn>2010-03-21</pav:createdOn>
        <pav:createdBy rdf:resource="http://www.hcklab.org/foaf.rdf#me"/>
    </rdf:Description>
}}}
